0: DETMOLD, Germany — An 88-year-old Auschwitz survivor who traveled from his home in California to Germany was denied the opportunity to testify at a former Nazi SS guard's trial Friday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Joshua Kaufman, who lives in Los Angeles, had hoped to win permission to tell the court about how he removed bodies from gas chambers at the World War II death camp after victims had been killed with Zyklon B. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Joshua Kaufman, an 88-year-old Holocaust survivor and father of four from Los Angeles, attends Friday's hearing with daughter Rachel Kaufman. Andy Eckardt / NBC News NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Reinhold Hanning, 94, is on trial accused of being accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people. Although Hanning was not directly involved in any killings at Auschwitz, prosecutors accuse him of facilitating the slaughter in his capacity as a guard at the camp. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Around 1.2 million people — most of them Jews — were killed at the site, which is located in Poland. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR More than a dozen witnesses have already testified in the trial and a verdict is expected on May 27. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At the start of Friday's session, Kaufman's German lawyer Markus Goldbach asked the court if his client could also be heard. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “He will be able to tell you that the bodies looked as if they were frozen and that he could see the horror of the death fight in their faces,” Goldbach said in his application statement. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I lost my whole family, I survived five concentration camps and I represent the dead people. They should at least respect me." "I lost my whole family, I survived five concentration camps and I represent the dead people. They should at least respect me." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The lawyer argued that his client would be able to give evidence of the specific killing process. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Judge Anke Grudda agreed to consider the request but after a break in the proceedings ruled that Kaufman would not be allowed to testify. She stressed that the decision was based entirely on German law and was not out of "reasons of respect or disrespect." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Speaking before the Grudda announced her ruling, Kaufman said he "came to speak for those who can no longer be heard."
